boardgame.name: Horrors of Egypt
boardgame.description:
From publisher blurb:

"You're too late to stop the ritual! Anubis lives again!"

The dark magic of ancient Egypt reach across time in illustrated tales of terror from legendary talents such as Joe Kubert and Al Camy.

Horrors of Egypt features six classic horror tales from the Golden Age of Comics, each chronicling the dire fates of those who awaken the ancient Egyptian gods and demons from their age-long slumber.

In addition to the comics, the book contains new rules to let roleplaying gamers create their own chilling tales of ancient evils awakened using the d20 Syatem. Designed by Steve Miller, known for his work on the Ravenloft gothic fantasy gameworld, these rules are fully compatible with other NUELOW Games d20 System supplements. While they are intended for use with OGL Modern, they are easily adaptable to your favorite d20 System variant.

boardgame.name: Monsters!
boardgame.description:
Monsters is a 2D action shooter inspired by the classic arcade game Robotron 2084. Wielding “twin stick” controls, the player aims to defeat waves of enemy monsters bent on his destruction. The player must use caution, however, as every shot drains the player’s life/energy. The only way to stay alive is to continuously collect the hearts of the slain monsters. In addition, hearts of different colors provide a variety of “power-up” like abilities that the player can use to their advantage.

The player uses two sets of controls, one to move, the other to fire. Each wave is a single screen populated with a number of enemy monsters of varying types. Coming into contact with an enemy or an enemy projectile will decrease the player’s life/energy. Defeating each level of monsters will allow the player to progress to a more difficult level. The game will progress infinitely as the player defeats each level.

Source: The Developer Website.

boardgame.name: The Three Lives of Fantomah: Book One
The Three Lives of Fantomah: Mystery Woman of the Jungle
boardgame.description:
From publisher blurb:

THE MOST FANTASTIC WOMAN TO HAVE EVER LIVED!

Fantomah, the mystery woman of the jungle, possesses vast supernatural powers that she uses to protect animals and people from evil. Those who enter her realm intent on doing harm will suffer punishments beyond their worst nightmares!

Fantomah first appeared in the pages of Jungle Comics #2 (Fiction House, 1940) and most comics historians identify her as the first female superhero. Over the course of 49 issues, the character went through three distinct stages that were so different from each other that it was almost as if three different characters were presented under the same name. In The Three Lives of Fantomah, NUELOW Games presents highlights from this often over-looked piece of comics history, together with roleplaying game material inspired by it.

The Three Lives of Fantomah: Book One presents a sampling of the bizarre comics of writer/artist Fletcher Hanks, together with a new OGL d20 System prestige class, feats and more. The rules are designed to capture the vast and fluid power of Fantomah, as well as anticipate the changes the character went through as the series evolved. Unlike most comic book characters, Fantomah got less powerful as time went by, something that led to some interesting and unusual game mechanics from Steve Miller (best known for contributions to the Ravenloft setting and several editions of Star Wars roleplaying games).

boardgame.name: Madden's Boys
boardgame.description:
From publisher blurb:

TEENAGE HEROES, STRAIGHT FROM THE GOLDEN AGE OF COMICS!

In 1941, artist Bill Madden drew five stories about teen heroes Dynamic Boy and Yankee Boy--one born from a desperate science experiment, the other from pure patriotism. Editor L.L. Hundal has exhumed these early superhero gems from the yellowed. discarded pages of Dynamic Comics 2-3 and Yankee Comics 2-4, and collected them here, in Madden's Boys, so Madden's unique and energetic art can once again be apprecated by comics fans everywhere.

In addition to the comics by Madden, the book also contains support for three different roleplaying game systems.

Designer Scott Capser brings Dynamic Boy and Yankee Boy to Great Scott Games' Hideouts & Hoodlums system.
L.L. Hundal adapts them to ROLF!: The Rollplaying Game of Big Dumb Fighters
Steve Miller brings them to OGL Modern games with an all new approach to using feats and talent trees to create Golden Age superheroes that is fully compatible with NUELOW's Feats of Mysticism & Magic and other OGL d20 products.

boardgame.name: Toxic Bunny
Toxic Bunny HD
boardgame.description:
Toxic Bunny is a side-scrolling action computer game for DOS computers released in 1996 by Celestial Games. The premise of the game is that a bunny named Toxic, a coffee guzzling, gun slinging maniac who is having a really bad day. The game covers four large levels in which Toxic hunts the person (or animal) responsible for interrupting his coffee break, brainwashing all his friends, and covering the planet with a decaffeinated goo. Within the game you can use any number of incredibly large weapons including a Nitric Hamster Launcher, while squashisng aliens with rusty nautical equipment.

Many say the game is a psychedelic parody of Epic Games character, Jazz Jackrabbit, due to similar game play and the fact that the main protagonist is also a rabbit. However the developers disagree, instead claiming inspirations from the popular 1994 game Earthworm Jim. Toxic Bunny is filled with an abundance of cheesy 90's references and high speed antics.

Toxic Bunny HD

Celestial Games, having re-opened in 2010, started porting Toxic Bunny to Java and decided to give the game a full revamp. This included reanimating sprites and redrawing all the levels. It was released as a boxed product in South Africa on 5 October 2012 under the name Toxic Bunny HD. It is also available for digital sale on the Celestial Games website.[4] The developers of the title, are currently building version 1.3 in Unity (Game Engine) which should be completed May 2013.

Source: Wikipedia, "Toxic Bunny", available under the CC-BY-SA License.

boardgame.name: Judy of the Jungle: The Lords of Memnon
boardgame.description:
From publisher blurb:

"MY DADDY TOLD ME TO NEVER TRUST A MAN!"

During the Golden Age of Comics, jungle adventure series were all the rage. In 1937, Will Eisner and Jerry Iger hit on the notion that a female jungle hero couldn't help but be popular with the core comic book audience what with the tendency of jungle heroes to not wear much in the way of clothes. So, into existence came Sheena... and shortly after that, the first "fan service" likewise appeared.

Judy of the Jungle debuted in 1947, ten years after Sheena. She first appeared in Exciting Comics #55 where she became popular enough to knock long-time title star Black Terror from the cover within two issues of her debut. She enjoyed a 15-issue run, before fading into history.

Judy may not have been the most groundbreaking of characters, but she was visually distinct from the many other Sheena wanna-bes--where they wore varations of a striped animal skin bikin (like Sheena), Judy's attire was a tattered cocktail dress. She may also have the most unique set of "daddy issues" in all of comicdom. Even better, her adventures never wanted for action.

And her series is titled Judy of the Jungle. This was a comic that was begging for a NUELOW Games edition.

Judy of the Jungle: The Lords of Memnon features the first four Judy adventures, and the debut adventure of the first black jungle hero--Voodah. In addition to 38 pages of great comics, the book includes an all new talent tree and starting occupatiuon designed to bring jungle action to your d20 OGL Mddern games.

Trivia: The creator of Voodah, Matt Baker, was among the first African Americans to draw comics for mainstream publishers.

boardgame.name: Judy of the Jungle: Warriors of the Laughing Hyena
boardgame.description:
From publisher blurb:

"THE JUNGLE IS NO PLACE FOR BEASTS LIKE YOU!"

Raised by her misanthrope of a naturalist father to feel more kinship with the animals of the African jungle than with other humans, young Judy champions wildlife and the wilderness along the Yazoo River. She only fully trusts Pistol Roberts, an American ranger. Her general distrust of humanity serves her well, as she finds herself the target of a corrupt big game hunter and comes into conflict with a former circus freak with dreams of building a jumgle empire in this second volume of "Judy of the Jungle" tales from NUELOW Games.

Judy of the Jugle: Warriors of Laughing Hyena features four great comics adventures--three by the character's creator Ralph Mayo, and one by the legendary Frank Frazetta--and two short stories by Charles S. Strong. Additionally, the book contains more rules for use with OGL d20 Modern jungle-based roleplaying games, like those found in the fist book in this series, July of the Jungle: The Lords of Memnon.

"Judy of the Jungle" was originally published by Nedor Comics, debuting as a secondary feature in Exciting Comics in 1947. She was featured in 15 short comics stories, and five fiction pieces. Judy's adventures hold up better than many of the entries in the "jungle girl" genre, which thrived in the pages of comics during the 1940s and early 1950s, including the famous Sheena. We hope that you'll find yourself enjoying these classic tales as much as we here at NUELOW Games do.

boardgame.name: Pat Patriot
boardgame.description:
From publisher blurb:

AMERICA'S JOAN OF ARC!

When first-generation American Patricia Patrios decided to complain about harsh working conditions on the factory assembly line, it started a series of events that would pit her against Nazi agents, gangsters, and other enemies of the American Dream. In 1941, as war-clouds gathered on America's shores, "Pat Patriot" became a symbol of the American spirit for the people to rally around.

Pat Patriot presents the four best adventures of this largely forgotten Golden Age patriotic female hero, who debuted several months before Wonder Woman. In addition to the classic comic book tales, the book features a complete ROLF! supplement in which sat is teamed with another great American hero, Bronze Terror!

Trivia: Pat Patriot (as well as the Bronze Terror) came to be during a long weekend of feverish creation when publisher Lev Gleason crammed writers and artists into a couple of hotel rooms to make content for a follow-up series to the one-shot Daredevil Battles Hitler. She was featured in Daredevil Comics 2 - 11 (Agu. 1941 - June 1942). The series title was intially used on an unrelated one-shot gag strip starring a blond teenaged boy.

boardgame.name: Warrior Maiden Starlight
boardgame.description:
From publisher blurb:

"I can stalk a deer and wing my shafts as well as any fledgling warrior!"

Starlight was as wild and tempesteous as the wendigo winds, and in her breast beat the heart of a warrior. She viewed with contempt the idea that women should be modest and content to cook and weave for the men who hunted and fended off the enemies of Huron people. So, she termed herself a warrior-maiden, and set out to prove that her arrows struck as true, and her knife cut as deep, as that wielded by any man.

Warrior Maiden Starlight chronicles the adventures of a strong-willed young woman, as she refuses to submit to gender roles in Huron society some two centuries before European settlers made contact with the Native Americans of the northeast.

Starlight was the last in a string of strong female characters to be featured in comics anthologoes from Fiction House, the most famous of these being Sheena, Queen of the Jungle. Originally published in Indians #2 - #8 in 1951, this book is the first time all seven installments of the series have been collected in one volume anywhere. This is a series and a character that don't deserve the total obsurity into which they have fallen, as it's one of the best of its kind. NUELOW Games hopes it will be rediscovered by many readers.

In addition to the classic comics by Ralph Mayo (artist of the Judy of the Jungle series, also available from NUELOW Games), Warrior Maiden Starlight features an outline for an OGL d20 game setting titled First Americans, which includes some new feats and game stats for the fearsome Wendio.

boardgame.name: Kathy
boardgame.description:
From publisher blurb:

"Oh, how super-scrumptious, Hank. Tonight we live!"

She's the queen of jukeboxes and hi-jinx, and now she's back!

Among the many genres that thrived during the Golden Age of Comics was the teen comedy, sometimes with romantic elements, sometimes not. One example of these was Standard's Kathy, a series that lasted eight epidodes in the anthology series Thrilling Comics and eventually being awarded its own title in 1954.

Kathy was at its best in the earliest episodes, with stories fast-paced stories that read like modern-day television sit-coms ahd which are blessed with art superior to almost any other teen comedy strips, as it was by the dream team of Frank Frazetta and Ralph Mayo.

NUELOW Games' Kathy collects all four of the Frazetta/Mayo-illustrated episodes in one place. The book may be of special interest to those like to examine the techinical aspects of comic book art, as Mayo and Frezaetta handle different aspects of the art on different stories.

In addition to the classic comics, Kathy includes a complete supplement for ROLF!: The Rollplaying Game of Big Dumb Fifghters. It features a story in which Kathy meets actress Linda Turner (secretly the Black Cat), four battle scenarios, seven pre-generated characters, and a selection of Traits and Battle Maneuvers not included in the main rulebook.

boardgame.name: Pollywog
boardgame.description:
User Summary

A simple pond simulation, Pollywog has you living the life of frogs. You start the game with a dozen eggs that hatch into a school of pollywogs (tadpoles). Control the school with the joystick and eat the algae. As the pollywogs eat they slowly mature into frogs. Avoid the orange creepies and the great white fish. They eat pollywogs and frogs, But frogs can eat the creepies as well.

Eating all the algae in the pond or eating all the creepies will advance you to another pond. There are 64 ponds and you'll advance as many pond as there are pollywogs left. If you have 10 pollywogs after the first pond, you'll advance to pond #11.

boardgame.name: Odyssey: The Compleat Apventure
boardgame.description:
Odyssey: The Compleat Apventure was a videogame written by Robert Clardy and released by Synergistic Software in 1980. It was created for the Apple II platform and is considered one of the first microcomputer-based role-playing video games. The title was intentionally misspelled; Apventure is a reference to the Apple computer.

A forerunner of Akalabeth and Ultima, Odyssey was a multi-part adventure game that placed the player in the role of the leader of an army who sets out to vanquish an evil wizard. Elements of Dungeons & Dragons can be found within the game, which combines elements of two earlier games written by Clardy: Dungeon Campaign and Wilderness Campaign.

The game features several major sections. Except for the endgame section, the game play is presented in a top-down map format with limited animation and sound effects.
Source: Wikipedia, "Odyssey: The Compleat Apventure", available under the CC-BY-SA License.

boardgame.description:
The game consists of 24 dice. Each die has a single letter on each side.

Each player rolls all the dice and places the resulting letters in a crossword style grid. The objective is to use as few words as possible while using all the letters. The player who needs the fewest words to use all the letters is the winner. The game can be played as a single round, multiple rounds, in teams or the players may choose pass the dice undisturbed to the other player or team so each is using the same letters to form a grid.

boardgame.name: PixelJunk 4am
boardgame.description:
PixelJunk 4am, formerly called PixelJunk Lifelike, is a music video game and music visualizer developed by Q-Games. It is part of the PixelJunk series of downloadable games for the PlayStation 3. PixelJunk 4am makes use of the PlayStation Move controller to visualize included music (by Baiyon) and users' own music. The first trailer was released in September 2010. The game was released on May 15, 2012.

Source: Wikipedia, "PixelJunk 4am", available under the CC-BY-SA License.
boardgame.videogamehonor: 2013 IGF Awards Excellence In Audio Nominee

boardgame.name: Project Offset
boardgame.description:
UNRELEASED GAME - CANCELLED




This game was cancelled in development. Please only submit images if you own a copy or have legal access to this item.




User Summary

Project Offset was going to be a high fantasy FPS built from the team's proprietary Offset engine. Intel bought the studio in early 2008 with the intention of using Project Offset to showcase its new Larrabee graphics tech. The company decided to abandon the project and disband the team two years later. Now Intel owns the Project Offset name as well as the Offset engine.

Combat would have had a fusion of close-quarters combat and long range shooting to create a high action experience. The game would also have featured rideable creatures such as Siege Trolls, Dragons and Battle Boars.
